user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CreateSocketName:
```c
void OS_CreateSocketName(const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, const char *parent_name)
{
    size_t                       len;
    uint16                       port;
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *sock;

    sock = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, *token);

    if (OS_SocketAddrToString_Impl(sock->stream_name, sizeof(sock->stream_name), Addr) != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        sock->stream_name[0] = 0;
    }
    if (OS_SocketAddrGetPort_Impl(&port, Addr) == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        len = OS_strnlen(sock->stream_name, sizeof(sock->stream_name));
        snprintf(&sock->stream_name[len], sizeof(sock->stream_name) - len, ":%u", (unsigned int)port);
    }

    if (parent_name)
    {
        /* Append the name from the parent socket. */
        len = OS_strnlen(sock->stream_name, sizeof(sock->stream_name));
        snprintf(&sock->stream_name[len], sizeof(sock->stream_name) - len, "-%s", parent_name);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CreateSocketName:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_stream_internal_record_t OS_stream_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char   stream_name[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    uint8  socket_domain;
    uint8  socket_type;
    uint16 stream_state;
} OS_stream_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    size_t            ActualLength; /**< @brief Length of the actual address data */
    OS_SockAddrData_t AddrData;     /**< @brief Abstract Address data */
} OS_SockAddr_t
...
int32 OS_SocketAddrToString_Impl(char *buffer, size_t buflen, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr)
{
    const void *                  addrbuffer;
    const OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *Accessor;

    Accessor = (const OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData;

    switch (Accessor->sa.sa_family)
    {
        case AF_INET:
            addrbuffer = &Accessor->sa_in.sin_addr;
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case AF_INET6:
            addrbuffer = &Accessor->sa_in6.sin6_addr;
            break;
#endif
        default:
            return OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS;
            break;
    }

    if (inet_ntop(Accessor->sa.sa_family, addrbuffer, buffer, buflen) == NULL)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
int32 OS_SocketAddrGetPort_Impl(uint16 *PortNum, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr)
{
    in_port_t                     sa_port;
    const OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *Accessor;

    Accessor = (const OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData;

    switch (Accessor->sa.sa_family)
    {
        case AF_INET:
            sa_port = Accessor->sa_in.sin_port;
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case AF_INET6:
            sa_port = Accessor->sa_in6.sin6_port;
            break;
#endif
        default:
            return OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS;
            break;
    }

    *PortNum = ntohs(sa_port);

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
static inline size_t OS_strnlen(const char *s, size_t maxlen)
{
    const char *end = (const char *)memchr(s, 0, maxlen);
    if (end != NULL)
    {
        /* actual length of string is difference */
        maxlen = end - s;
    }
    return maxlen;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other pointer usages in the provided code do not need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 because they are already const-qualified where appropriate or must be non-const because they are written to: - Function parameters: Addr and parent_name are declared as const (const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, const char *parent_name) and therefore satisfy the rule. - OS_SocketAddrToString_Impl takes a non-const char *buffer because the function writes into the buffer (cannot be const). - OS_SocketAddrGetPort_Impl takes uint16 *PortNum which is an output parameter (must be non-const). - The code writes to sock->stream_name, so the pointer to the stream table element must be a non-const OS_stream_internal_record_t * in this context. - The Accessor assignments in OS_SocketAddrToString_Impl and OS_SocketAddrGetPort_Impl cast &Addr->AddrData to a const accessor pointer; these are already const-qualified. - OS_strnlen has a const char * parameter (correct). The only places that could hide a const-qualification problem are the OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro and its use: the macro takes the address of its tok argument (&(tok)) and the call passes *token (a const object), which can lead to a const-qualification mismatch depending on the signature of OS_ObjectIndexFromToken (not provided). Therefore these macro-related fragments are reported for investigation; all other pointer uses in the shown code are either correctly const-qualified or intentionally non-const because they are modified.
